title: Before 15 March 2021, will there be a lethal confrontation between the national military forces of Iran and the United States either in Iran or at sea?
preds:
Comments: Incremental adjustment down.
The Times of Israel, 03/14/21, 'Israeli officials said to push calmer waters with Iran after alleged ship blasts': https://www.timesofisrael.com/israeli-officials-said-to-push-calmer-waters-with-iran-after-alleged-ship-blasts/
'With a new administration in Washington that is still forming policy and engaging in ongoing indirect diplomacy with Iran to save the faltering 2015 nuclear deal, aggressive action would not be the right course, one official advised.'
It's quite not likely to have lethal confrontation currently with the pandemic.

It is 0 because there are just 2 days left for the specific question (deadline, territory of attack). 
However, the chances are high in the short-medium term as per the recent attacks in Iraq forces suspected to be Iran. The US has restrained so far but along with other foreign ministers, issued a statement condemning the 20 Feb attack. 
https://www.arabnews.com/node/1814131/middle-east

Confrontation between US and Iran tends to occur out of Iranian space. E.g. Iraq (Soleimani) and recent retaliations by Iran against US Forces (February Iranian ballistic missile attack on Al Asad Airbase in Iraq).  Retaliation by the US may be likely via drone strikes.  But, strikes may be against Iranian militia within Iraq.  A confrontation between Israel and Iran seems more likely at this time given Abraham Accord (https://thediplomat.com/2021/03/israel-iran-and-china-us-middle-east-relations/ )
U.S. attacked Iran backed forces in Syria, in Feb., but pretty close to March 15 now.

They are trying to get back to the nuclear deal started and then stoped by trump administration.
No country wants a war with the pandemic still at the forefront.
Deadline is approaching quickly. Reducing to zero.

I think there is a possibility but unlikely. Israel has been suspected of carrying out assassinations within Iran. There would most likely be U.S. Military strikes against Iranian backed militias in Iraq and Syria. President Biden authorized attacks on Iranian back militias in Syria on February 26 to prevent further attacks on US troops operating in Iraq and Syria.
President Biden said during his campaign that he wants to reenter the 2015 Iran Nuclear Agreement that President Trump withdrew from. It would be difficult to continue nuclear talks with Iran if the threat of war was on the horizon. 
After President Trump ordered General Qasem Soleimani’s assassination, Iran’s Revolutionary Guard sent a retaliatory rocket attack against Al-Asad Air Base and base outside Irbil holding American troops in Iraq. Iran warned Iraq the attack was coming to prevent Iraqi deaths claiming they were only targeting the Americans in retaliation but also warned American allies their bases could be targeted as well.
Afterwards Iranian authorities gave mixed messages:
Iran’s Supreme Leader Ayatollah Khamenei and Iran’s President Hassan Rouhani both claimed Iran’s “final answer would be to kick all US forces out of the region”.
Iran’s Defense Minister Amir Hatami said, “Iran’s response to any US retaliation would be proportional to US actions.”
Iran’s Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif claimed “the attack was in self defense and denied seeking to escalate the situation into war.”
If the US wants any agreement with Iran it will not initiate any direct military response unless it is to deter direct attacks against the United States. Initiating direct military attacks against Iran would also worsen American relationships with China and Russia since they are both Iranian allies.
If Iran took unprovoked military actions against the United States it would lose its stance on the world stage that it wants to reengage with diplomacy. It could also lead to Iran’s isolation on the world stage, could see more economic sanctions, and could see other American allies, join in military retaliation.
After Iran’s retaliatory attacks, UK’s Prime Minister Boris Johnson warned Iran not to repeat any reckless or dangerous attacks, and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Israel would strike back hard against any attacks. https://foreignpolicy.com/2021/02/01/congress-biden-iran-nuclear-deal/

https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-51028954

There is a slim chance that a lethal confrontation will occur. Tensions are high right now between Iran and the United States. B-52s have just recently flown over Iran as a warning from the U.S (U.S. News, 2021). Due to there only being a little more than a week to go there is a small chance that a lethal confrontation will occur. https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/north-dakota/articles/2021-03-07/b-52s-again-fly-over-mideast-in-us-military-warning-to-iran

It is unlikely that a lethal confrontation between national military forces will occur. Recent displays of violence cannot be interpreted as trends. While minor instances may occur, proxy forces are much more likely to sustain casualties, and this question does not seem to cover mercenaries/state supported terrorist organizations.

Probability: 1% There is almost no chance that there will be a lethal confrontation between the national military forces of Iran and the United States before 15 March, 2021.  In 2015, the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA) was signed between Iran and several world powers, including the US, during the Obama administration. The JCPOA is more commonly referred to in the US as the “Iran Nuclear Deal.” Since the US withdrew from the agreement in 2018 under the Trump administration, Iran has restarted various activities related to nuclear programs (Robinson).  With the transition to the Biden regime, both the US and Iran have expressed willingness to re-engage in negotiations, or at least, to dialogue. During press briefings provided by the US Department of State during the first week of March, Department Spokesperson Ned Price discussed negotiations with Iran, stating that those in the US administration “remain ready to re-engage in meaningful diplomacy to achieve a mutual return to compliance under the JCPOA commitments” (Price). In Iranian Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei’s first speech of 2021, he focused on the JCPOA and emphasized the need to lift sanctions, but rejected possible talks on Iran’s missile development and regional activities (“Iran File”). Backing up this position, on March 4, 2021, Iranian Foreign Minister Javad Zarif tweeted that “JCPOA cannot be renegotiated,” and that countries should “get down to implementing JCPOA – which we both actually signed on to” (@JZarif). In February 2021, Iran announced it will place new restrictions on the IAEA’s ability to conduct inspections of its facilities. However, some of the restrictions will not take effect for three months, a window of time that analysts say could be intended as an opening for diplomacy (Robinson).  A lethal military conflict between two major parties of the JCPOA would almost certainly derail the negotiations that both sides have expressed a willingness to approach. Given the opportunities for Iran to obtain relief from sanctions and a resumption of foreign aid, and the looming Iranian Presidential elections in June 2021, it doesn’t make sense for them to engage in military conflict with the US at this time. If the Obama administration’s policies are indicative of what Biden’s may be, it seems more likely that Biden will approach Iran with bribes, rather than bullets. As there are only 11 days until the end of the time period in this forecast, I think there is nearly no chance of a lethal confrontation taking place. Sources: @JZarif. “JCPOA cannot be renegotiated—period. If 2021 is not 2015, it's not 1945 either. So let's change UN Charter & remove the veto—so often abused by US. Let's stop posturing—which we both did 2003-2012 to no avail—& get down to implementing JCPOA—which we both actually signed on to.” Twitter, March 4, 2021, 11:24am, https://twitter.com/JZarif/status/1367526457254309888. “Iran File.” Critical File. https://www.criticalthreats.org/briefs/iran-file. Accessed March 4, 2021. Price, Ned. “Department Press Briefing – March 1, 2021.” United States Department of State. https://www.state.gov/briefings/department-press-briefing-march-1-2021/#post-222719-Iran. Accessed March 4, 2021. Robinson, Kali. “What Is the Iran Nuclear Deal?” Council on Foreign Relations. February 25, 2021. https://www.cfr.org/backgrounder/what-iran-nuclear-deal. Accessed March 4, 2021.

With 8 days left until this deadline, it's less likely that a lethal confrontation will occur in that small of a window. However, I think it is likely the Iranian forces will attack US bases in the area again in the near future.  Recently on March 3rd, there was an attack carried out on the Ain al-Asad airbase in Iraq. No one has claimed responsibility yet for the attack, but considering the attack came from the east of the base, the finger seems to be pointing towards Iran. I had to google where the base was, and since it's not technically on the map due to protection, I was unable to find the exact location. Thankfully, Military Auto Source likes to market itself as best as possible, so they have successfully given a roundabout position of where the base most likely is. One contractor died from a cardiac "episode" while hiding during the bombing.  This kind of attack is the typical tit for tat that occurs in this area and will likely continue. Khamenei has also been very vocal recently about retaliation against the United States. He called it a "slap to the face" of Americans and also said, "military action is not sufficient, what is important is that the seditious American presence in the region must end." If this is the kind of vocalization being passed to the people of Iran, then I expect this to become more of a conflict. If the time span for this prediction were longer, then I would raise the percentage. The Iranians are also still very upset about the bombing of Soleimani in January of 2020. To them, the United States killed a very influential leader. It would be similar to if the Iranians took out General Petraeus. The animosity from that attack still hasn't gone away after a year.    https://www.scmp.com/news/world/middle-east/article/3123976/us-contractor-dies-rocket-attack-iraq-base

I feel as though this would be more likely to happen later in the future, however with only 8 days left until the deadline, it's more unlikely. There has not been any recent leads to assume that a lethal confrontation between Iran and the U.S will occur just next week. However, with Biden's recent airstrike and previous tensions between the U.S and Iran, I wouldn't make this a 0% chance in happening.

Such an event is not unlikely, but with only 8 days left until the deadline, there is not a necessarily high probability of a lethal confrontation between the national military forces of Iran and the United States.  I am not predicting this to be close to 0% though because there is an active ‘tit-for-tat’ happening between the US and Iran.  “President Joe Biden on Thursday [February 25 2021] ordered airstrikes on buildings in Syria that the Pentagon said were used by Iranian-backed militias, in retaliation for rocket attacks on U.S. targets in neighboring Iraq” (De Luce, Gains, Gubash & Welker 2021).  “A pair of B-52 bombers flew over the Mideast on Sunday, the latest such mission in the region aimed at warning Iran amid tensions between Washington and Tehran” (Gambrell 2021).  American show of force following Iran suspected attacks could spark an official retaliation from Iranian military forces.  “The flight by the two heavy bombers came as a pro-Iran satellite channel based in Beirut broadcast Iranian military drone footage of an Israeli ship hit by a mysterious explosion only days earlier in the Mideast” (Gambrell 2021).   Many run-ins with Iranian backed forces have been militia groups, which do not fall under the parameters of this question. But again, the American show of force, and the fact that there is tension between the US and Iran surrounding a nuclear deal, leads me to forecast on the higher side of low, at 23%.  De Luce, D., Gains, M., Gubash, C., & Welker, K. (2021). Biden orders airstrikes in Syria, retaliating against Iran-backed militias. https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/biden-airstrikes-syria-retaliating-against-iran-backed-militias-n1258912
Gambrell, J. (2021). US B-52s again fly over Mideast in warning to Iran. https://www.airforcetimes.com/news/your-military/2021/03/07/us-b-52s-again-fly-over-mideast-in-warning-to-iran/

Comments: Seeing increasing volatility in region attributed to surrogates. Affirming forecast.
The Jerusalem Post, 03/07/21, 'Hijacking, riots and explosions: Iran’s regime tested amid tensions': https://www.jpost.com/middle-east/hijacking-riots-and-explosions-irans-regime-tested-amid-tensions-661194
Clips from JP article:
'The increase in arrests of Kurds by the IRGC is part of the same pattern in Baluchistan and in Ahvaz. It is not like these three incidents are all just random. In each area, the corps has usurped the powers of the government to conduct most of Iran’s operations.
In each place, it is also clear that unrest is boiling beneath the surface. The face that Iran tries to project beyond its borders, of power and strength, belies a very real series of problems closer to home.
The overall context is that Iran is also suffering from COVID-19 and is implementing various travel regulations and trying to cope with continued sanctions.
Although it says its indigenous industry can keep up with the challenges, it has invested heavily in weapons, such as ballistic missiles, and neglects some industries at home.'
The Daily Sabah, 03/07/21, 'Iran-backed militia leader threatens to take up arms against Turkey': https://www.dailysabah.com/politics/war-on-terror/iran-backed-militia-leader-threatens-to-take-up-arms-against-turkey
Al-Jazeera, 03/05/21, 'Gantz says Israel has list of Iran-backed targets ready to strike': https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/3/5/gantz-says-israel-has-list-of-iran-backed-targets-ready-to-strike

With less than 10 days remaining in the timeline of this prediction, and as things continue as they have in the last two months, there is less and less likelihood that a lethal confrontation will happen by 15 March, 2021.

Iran and the US seem to be employing their rockets in a game of tit for tat Iran retaliated for Biden's rocket strike in Syria with an attack on an Iraqi air base where American soldiers were known to be. Tensions are high and will likely continue to be high as they have been. However, at the rate things are going right now, I don't think that this game will escalate to lethal confrontation in the next 9 days. The possibility is not 0%, though, in my opinion considering the US's willingness to use projectile weapons in these confrontations.  https://www.nytimes.com/2021/02/25/us/politics/biden-syria-airstrike-iran.html
https://www.usnews.com/news/world-report/articles/2021-03-03/iraqi-airbase-housing-us-troops-attacked-by-rockets-iran-militia-believed-involved

In my assessment, there is a very low chance of lethal confrontation occurring between national military forces of Iran and the United States either in Iran or at Sea. This is due to numerous factors. For one, Iran and the United States are not formally at war. Even with the two being at war, this scenario would still be somewhat unlikely, as non-combat deaths make up more than 70% of all deaths that the US military has recently suffered (Congressional Research Service, 2020). This happening within the next week in a half is highly unlikely, which is why I gave this scenario a 1% likelihood. Reference:
Congressional Research Service. (2020). Trends in Active-Duty Military Deaths Since 2006. Congressional Research Service. Retrieved March 5, 2021, from https://fas.org/sgp/crs/natsec/IF10899.pdf

Both sides will continue to compete through proxies. Pres.Biden will not be taking further offensive actions without Congressional approval.
See Senator Tim Kaine.

Tensions don't seem to be letting up anytime soon, especially with the recent rocket strikes and retaliatory strikes by the US in Syria. While I don't think it will escalate much more in the 9 days remaining-there is a chance that something will happen that leads to a fatality, especially in the "tit for tat" game that Iran is playing with the United States.

Relations between the U.S. and Iran are still severe. A deadly encounter between each side's national military forces could result in casualties. Even Though there is tension between the two countries there is most likely a 0% chance for a confrontation to occur by March 15th.

While there continues to be tensions between the U.S. and Iran, particularly within the borders of Iraq and Iran-backed militia’s launching rocket attacks at bases housing U.S. troops (https://www.politico.com/news/2021/03/04/iran-group-responsible-iraq-attack-473618) as well as the U.S. launching airstrikes against Iran-backed militia in Syria on February 15, 2021 (https://www.politico.com/news/2021/03/04/iran-group-responsible-iraq-attack-473618). The likelihood of a lethal confrontation between the national military forces of Iran and the U.S. is highly unlikely. There is likely to be continued tension and confrontations both within Syria and Iraq but also at sea, yet the likelihood of a deadly confrontation would likely be as a result of a miscalculation or misstep as the any death of a U.S. military member by an Iranian military member would likely result in a broader campaign against Iran by the U.S. This is not in Iran’s best interest and it would be far better for Iran to continue to support militia’s and proxy groups that can wage more open attacks against U.S. interests in the region.
It is currently March 4th and there appears to be no news of rising tensions.

On February 15th, 2021, pro-Iran militias fired rockets at a U.S. airbase in Iraq’s Kurdistan region, injuring 9 (including Americans) and killing 1 (foreign civilian contractor). Five days later, on February 20th, Balad Airbase in Iraq's Saladin Governorate was targeted by another rocket attack. A South African civilian contractor working for the U.S. was injured in the attack. In response to the Erbil attack, President Biden ordered airstrikes against Kata'ib Hezbollah facilities in Syria on February 26th. The attack may have killed over a dozen people/militants. The most recent attack occurred on March 3rd, when Al Asad air base in Iraq – housing U.S. and collation troops – were targeted by a rocket attack. A U.S. civilian contractor suffered a heart attack during the strike and died.  These attacks are part of the 2019-2021 Persian Gulf Crisis, and many attacks involve proxies – not Iran’s official military. There has not been a recent confrontation (2021) between the official military forces of Iran and the U.S. in Iran or at sea. Therefore, despite recent casualties, these attacks do not constitute such a scenario. Additionally, Pope Francis has a scheduled visit to Iraq which will last from March 5th to March 7th. If there are no attacks during this three-day period, proxy attacks may resume after the Pope departs. Iran denies involvement in these attacks, making it unlikely that an outright military confrontation would occur between U.S. forces and Iranian armed forces in Iran or at sea before March 15th. I give this scenario a probability score of 5%.

Given that the deadline for this prediction is in less than two weeks, I believe that the likelihood that there will be a lethal confrontation between the national military forces of Iran and the U.S. either in Iran or at sea depends on whether there are indicators of an immediate conflict or attack. Tensions between the US and Iran definitely rose during Trump's time in office, stemming from actions such as withdrawing the US from the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA) in 2018 and the assassination of Qasem Soleimani in 2020. With the new administration, many are hoping for a shift in dynamic between the two countries; however, with the Biden administration joining European partners in an effort to begin talks with Iran for the first time in several years to settle differences and revive the 2015 nuclear deal, as well as the recent attacks on US bases in the Middle East and Biden's decision to strike Iranian-linked groups in Syria in late February, it is uncertain whether relations between the US and Iran will worsen or better in the following months. But the US and Iran are in a very precarious situation right now, with both sides avoiding a direct military confrontation, instead attacking each other through the US imposing economic sanctions, Iran targeting US allies (such as Saudi Arabia and Israel), and both engaging in conflict through Iranian-backed proxy forces (like Ketaib Hezbollah). These conflicts have mostly occurred in other countries, specifically Iraq, making it even less likely that there will be a confrontation between the two within Iran or at sea. If any lethal confrontation were to occur in the next two weeks, it will be an attack on a US base by Iran-backed militants or a US strike against Iranian proxies, but there is a very low chance that there will be a lethal military confrontation between the national military forces of Iran and the United States military either in Iran or at sea. However, given the current delicate environment, I will never say never, so I am giving a 1% likelihood of occurrence.
Biden appears to wish to resolve the issue, albeit perhaps in the model of JCPOA "plus". I am updating mainly though only to factor for elapsed time as the basic factors seem pretty much the same.
Iran has been flexing its military forces and seems agitated by U.S. relations currently, but the likelihood of a fatal confrontation remains low.

Wednesday, March 3rd, Ain al-Asad air base came under attack. No uniformed U.S. troops were injured however it will be interesting to see how this plays out.  This attack comes after the US launched a strike on Iranian-backed militia targets in Syria. This type of tit-for-tat almost led Iran and the U.S to the brink of war last year

I think there is a very very small chance that Biden would initiate a confrontation between Iran and the United States. He created a large plan for his first 100 days, that is mainly centered around decreasing COVID-19 numbers. It would be too much to deal with Before March 15, 2021. I do think that it is a likely possibility that Biden would choose to use nuclear weapons on Iran in the future.
Biden unlikely to raise tensions with Iran during his first 100 days.

Virtually no chance of conflict on Iranian soil. 
With both US and Iran both focused on domestic issues in the mains, only a small outlier chance of a seaborne conflict.
The US has a large military presence in the countries neighbouring Iran's southern borders. 
The US has very recently sent a 3rd warship into the Black Sea to the north of Iran, in a measure to step up it's military presence in the region.
Iran is heavily outgunned by US forces surrounding Iran in the region.

Seeing as how the deadline for this prediction is in less than two weeks, there would need to be indicators of an imminent attack for there to be any likelihood of this happening.  Iran has recently refused offers from the European Union to engage the United States directly in talks regarding a rejoining of the Joint Cooperative Plan of Action, levying a requirement for the US to alleviate economic sanctions prior to such a conversation.  Some believe Iran is looking for an opportunity to avenge the January 2020 assassination of General Qasem Soleimani, with Iranian judiciary chief Ebrahim Raisi going as far as to say their revenge is “close at hand” during a meeting with Faiq Zidan, Head of the Iraqi Supreme Judicial Council in Baghdad.  If Iran were to conduct an attack against US forces on land, it would likely continue to leverage a proxy-force such as the Kataib Hezbollah as they have in the past, reducing the chances the US would retaliate with an attack across the Iranian border.  Kayhan, a hardline Iranian media outlet, recently cited unnamed “military experts” in crediting Iran with an attack on the MV Helios Ray, an Israeli vehicle carrier, off the coast of Oman, indicating probable Iranian capability and intent to execute such attacks against perceived threats.  The US Naval Institute indicated that as of 1 March 2021, the Makin Island Amphibious Ready Group (ARG) is currently located in the Persian Gulf, providing a possible, albeit incredibly well-defended, target for a potential attack such as seen with the MV Helios Ray.  Two factors inhibit this option for Iran; first the attack would be highly unlikely to be successful against a large group of US naval ships sure to be on alert in their current geographic location and secondly the political ramifications Iran would suffer if their direct involvement were discovered could see the loss of support from the European Union, causing further economic hardships for the country.  Based on this information, I cannot completely rule out the chances of either the US or the Iranian Revolutionary Guard Corps suffering a fatality at sea over the next two weeks, but it is extremely unlikely.  Due to the short suspense for this forecast and the significantly remote chance of this occurring, I will grant a 1% chance this may occur in the next two weeks and a 99% chance that any conflict, if it does occur, will continue through proxy-forces in Iraq and/or Syria.
short time frame, pandemic focused right now
With the current tension between Syria and the USA, it is not likely they would extend hostilities to Iran.
Changing to the crowd forecast because with 13 days left, the chance is remote.

A conflict may happen due to the provoking by any of the two sides, by any one of the parties who belong to the two sides. US is going slow in its announcement to return to the nuclear treaty between the two sides.  It may not start any conflict. Iran, on the other hand, is facing hardships due to the pandemic, sanctions and pressure is increasing from within.  Iran has also avowed to take action against the killing of its military leader. Iran is also due for a presidential election in June.  A hardliner within may want to initiate a conflict to divert the ongoing problems or preparation for the election. 
However, the chances of Iran initiating a conflict may be very remote in the near future. 
There may also be conflict initiated by a third party who may not to see improving relationship between US-Iran.
I don't expect anything to happen with military forces in such a short time frame
Biden seems to be following in Obama's footsteps, so drone strikes could possibly be in Iran's future.
I chose this because I think there is a very low chance that this will happen but it is a possibility that Iran would feel the need to retaliate in some way.
Upping to 10% - still remote, but the US bombing of Iranian-backed militias in Syria is concerning. (https://us.cnn.com/2021/02/25/politics/us-iraq-iran/index.html)

Very little chance, especially with a Biden Presidency. Tensions have died down since the killing of Qassem Soleimani. The nuclear deal and lifting of sanctions is an "olive branch" but there's some relationship repairing that both sides are interested in. (https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-02-19/u-s-iran-standoff-shows-difficulty-of-salvaging-nuclear-deal.) Barring something we don't already know I'll say the chances are remote, although never 0.

Potential for accidental clash at sea which results in a fatality, particularly if both sides are attempting to exert influence ahead of nuclear talks. Potential for elements of the IRGC to seek to derail talks. Limited time frame from assessment (20 days), place this at the lowest possible risk.

Comments: Black swan event(s) perpetrated by Israeli or Iranian hardliners to derail diplomatic efforts keep me at my current forecast.
Bloomberg, 02/21/21, 'Iran Compromise With Atomic Monitors Taps Brakes on Escalation': https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-02-21/iran-compromise-with-atomic-monitors-taps-brakes-on-escalation
CNBC, 02/21/21, 'U.S. has started to talk with Iran about detained Americans, Biden national security advisor says': https://www.cnbc.com/2021/02/21/us-has-started-to-communicate-with-iran-over-detained-americans.html
US News, 02/20/21, 'Iran Says Studies EU-Proposed Informal Meeting With U.S.': https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2021-02-20/iran-spokesman-says-tehran-confident-about-lifting-of-us-sanctions-despite-wrangling
VOA, 02/18/21, 'Source: US Informed Israel Ahead of Iran Policy Announcement': https://www.voanews.com/middle-east/voa-news-iran/source-us-informed-israel-ahead-iran-policy-announcement

President Biden offered to come to the table to discuss a nuclear deal with Iran.  The United States would like to open negotiations with Iran that includes other world powers who participated in the JCPOA talks.  The Biden Administration also reversed sanctions on Iran and eased travel restrictions of Iranian diplomats.  These are large signals to Iran that the United States would like to work together.  Additionally, Iran has been requesting an ease on the sanctions imposed by the United States for some time now.  With these events unfolding, the likelihood of there being a lethal confrontation between Iran and the United States plummeted.  https://www.nytimes.com/2021/02/18/us/politics/biden-iran-nuclear.html
https://apnews.com/article/biden-iran-nuclear-deal-d261fbe927984d9328db0e0f74b62410

1) The U.S. has removed its Carrier Strike Group from the region.  This decreases the military tension in the region.  While it could be argued that now is the time for Iran to "kill" a U.S. Navy sailor because the U.S. is not in a position to respond, that just really isn't the case.  There are still plenty of US Navy assets in the region that could respond, as well as US Air Force that could strike the Iranian military.   2) The Biden Administration has initiated calls to resume JCPOA talks.  Iran has demanded that the US lift sanctions by 21 Feb or else Iran will expel IAEA monitors.  While the two nations hold preliminary talks via the media and third party nations to resume face to face talks, neither nation would want to take action that would put those talks at jeopardy.   The risk of miscalculation is always a concern and an on-scene commander could decide to fire at opposing forces in self-defense, but I suspect both nations are issuing rather clear guidance to commanders that they should exercise restraint until JCPOA plays out.

Decreasing due to NATO’s decision to increase number of troops in Iraq ( https://www.defense.gov/Explore/News/Article/Article/2507564/nato-defense-leaders-agree-to-increase-iraqi-mission-defer-decision-on-afghanis/). This will likely regarded as an adequate response to Thursday’s attack by Iranian-backed militia (https://news.google.com/articles/CAIiEN7eh9qWe19oGuMCBI7W_R8qGAgEKg8IACoHCAowjtSUCjC30XQw_qe5AQ?hl=en-US&gl=US&ceid=US%3Aen). Any direct attack on Iran would further impede Biden’s ability to negotiate with Iran.

US has expressed interest in renewing talks with Iran on denuclearization.  This will likely further decrease the risk of a lethal confrontation between the two nations. https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/biden-to-reassert-us-leadership-in-global-diplomacy-and-welcome-talks-with-iran/2021/02/18/76c6bb2c-724e-11eb-93be-c10813e358a2_story.html

Adjusting up due to recent news from Iraq (https://www.newsweek.com/us-base-attack-forces-joe-biden-juggle-retaliation-iran-nuclear-deal-hopes-1569887). Waiting for the decision of the Wed-Thurs NATO conference.
Refreshing the forecast. While time has indeed elapsed that has not changed the underlying calculation.

Upon further research, I have come to the conclusion that this is a classic example of the chicken game. Both parties need to negotiate, as Iran needs the sanctions to be lifted, and the United States wants to prevent Iran from pursuing nuclear arms development.  (https://news.cgtn.com/news/2021-02-14/Iran-vs-U-S-Who-will-blink-first--XQCMSztMvS/index.html). But the biggest hurdle is the potential damage to the country's image. If either country states that it wants to start negotiations it will lose face, and appear as the weaker of the two powers. With this in mind as with the chicken game, there are four outcomes. Two of them involve either power wanting to negotiate, the other involves both countries agreeing to negotiate and the final one is both countries refuse to negotiate and this would lead to an escalation. Especially with the United States' seizure of Iranian oil(https://www.aljazeera.com/economy/2021/2/15/tehran-calls-us-seizure-of-iranian-oil-an-act-of-piracy), this may lead to an accidental or purposeful lethal confrontation. Therefore I predict that there is a 25% chance of a lethal confrontation.

I can find  no instances of a lethal confrontation between U.S. and Iranian military forces inside Iran or at sea since at least the 1979 Iranian Revolution.  Conflict between Iranian proxy forces (primarily Kata’ib Hezbollah) and U.S. military forces in Iraq occurs several times each year.  However, retaliatory strikes remain confined to forces stationed inside Iraq.  Iran also routinely seizes and sabotages foreign ships transiting the Persian Gulf.  However, I found no evidence of Iran targeting U.S. military or civilian vessels.  In 2019, Iran did shoot-down a U.S. RQ-4 flying near its border, however, this does not qualify as a “lethal” confrontation as the RQ-4 is unmanned.  Both the U.S. and Iran seem to recognize that attacking one another’s forces inside Iran or at sea is a significant escalation neither side is willing to make. In the last two weeks, both Iran (Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei) and the U.S. (President Biden) made statements expressing their desire to renew the “Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA), AKA the 2015 Iran nuclear deal.  This will be a several months-long process, during which both the U.S. and Iran will seek to avoid unnecessary conflict. The most likely source of lethal confrontation will come from strategic miscalculation or provocation from elements of the Iranian Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC) not strictly adhering to rules of engagement.  For example, on 15 April 2020, eleven IRGS fast attack vessels harassed six U.S. vessels conducting a training exercise in the Arabian Gulf.  While neither side exchanged warning shots, the IRGC ships came within 10 yards of U.S. vessels.  This tactical-level provocation could have easily resulted in a lethal confrontation.  While the probability of this is higher than an exogenous event, it is still very low.  I found three similar incidents of IRGC maritime “harassment” over the past four years, for a rate of one per year.  The probability of a similar incident occurring before 15 March is 1 in 6, or 16%.  However, there is no precedent for one of these incidents turning lethal.   Therefore, I’ll only ascribe a 5% chance of lethal confrontation between now and 15 March.

The base rate for this class of events is low. If we take the base rate from last year (which is probably higher than average over time) of one chance in 12 that a lethal confrontation between IR and US national military forces takes place in a given month, you get about a 16% chance (8% x 2 months) that a lethal confrontation would occur between now (15 jan) and 15 March. I thought this base rate would be too high relative to the average over time, but just researching a little, it seems that US strikes have targeted IR troops in Syria over the past few years, so it might not be that much higher than the post-9/11 average. The base rate also should be moderated by the many factors the crowd has pointed out already, some of which nudge the probability upward and some downward: increased US presence in Gulf at present (up); Iranian exercises in Gulf upcoming (up); legislative determination to ramp up nuclear production (up); a new administration (down); promise for a reentry/renegotiation of the JCPOA (down); economic problems internally (down); COVID preoccupation (down).  The myriad particular factors almost end in a wash but my gut says 16% is too high to be reasonable, so dropping down to 12% to allow for unintended lethality (accidents, troops acting without authorization) and the desire to create favorable relations for a new US administration.

U.S. Code
Notes
prev | next
As used in this chapter—
(1)the term “international terrorism” means activities that—
(A)involve violent acts or acts dangerous to human life that are a violation of the criminal laws of the United States or of any State, or that would be a criminal violation if committed within the jurisdiction of the United States or of any State;
(B)appear to be intended—
(i)to intimidate or coerce a civilian population;
(ii)to influence the policy of a government by intimidation or coercion; or
(iii)to affect the conduct of a government by mass destruction, assassination, or kidnapping; and
(C)occur primarily outside the territorial jurisdiction of the United States, or transcend national boundaries in terms of the means by which they are accomplished, the persons they appear intended to intimidate or coerce, or the locale in which their perpetrators operate or seek asylum;
(2)the term “national of the United States” has the meaning given such term in section 101(a)(22) of the Immigration and Nationality Act;
(3)the term “person” means any individual or entity capable of holding a legal or beneficial interest in property;
(4)the term “act of war” means any act occurring in the course of—
(A)declared war;
(B)armed conflict, whether or not war has been declared, between two or more nations; or
(C)armed conflict between military forces of any origin;
(5)the term “domestic terrorism” means activities that—
(A)involve acts dangerous to human life that are a violation of the criminal laws of the United States or of any State;
(B)appear to be intended—
(i)to intimidate or coerce a civilian population;
(ii)to influence the policy of a government by intimidation or coercion; or
(iii)to affect the conduct of a government by mass destruction, assassination, or kidnapping; and
(C)occur primarily within the territorial jurisdiction of the United States; and
(6)the term “military force” does not include any person that—
(A)has been designated as a—
(i)foreign terrorist organization by the Secretary of State under section 219 of the Immigration and Nationality Act (8 U.S.C. 1189); or
(ii)specially designated global terrorist (as such term is defined in section 594.310 of title 31, Code of Federal Regulations) by the Secretary of State or the Secretary of the Treasury; or
(B)has been determined by the court to not be a “military force”.
(Added Pub. L. 102–572, title X, § 1003(a)(3), Oct. 29, 1992, 106 Stat. 4521; amended Pub. L. 107–56, title VIII, § 802(a), Oct. 26, 2001, 115 Stat. 376; Pub. L. 115–253, § 2(a), Oct. 3, 2018, 132 Stat. 3183.)er

While there is daily contact between Iranian naval forces and the US Navy throughout the Arabian Gulf region, I cannot recall a time in the last 5-10 years that those confrontations have resulted in the death of a servicemember from either nation.  Such an occurrence would probably result in a significant escalation in the region, so it is not in either nation's interest to have such an event occur.  Both nations seem to favor proxy warfare or engaging one another in a "perceived" neutral location, e.g. Iraq or Yemen.  As someone who has spent months onboard a US Navy ship in the region, the near-daily contact between the forces and the tensions that exist means that the probability cannot be reduced too low.

As the anniversary of the Soleimani strike has come and gone with little movement on Iran's part it is hard to believe that there will be an intentional violent confrontation. Instead, despite US domestic issues, Iran seems to be pursuing a more legalistic approach to the the US by issuing arrest warrants, as well as likely inciting Iraq to the do the same. This approach is more beneficial to the Iranian regime as it likely expects the incoming Biden administration to move back towards the JCPOA. If Iran inflames tensions and it results in death(s), a return to the deal will become more unlikely. With the tensions in the region lethal confrontations remain possible, but both sides have shown a willingness to avoid death even when discord climaxes. https://www.cnn.com/2021/01/07/world/iraq-arrest-warrant-trump-al-muhandis-intl/index.html
https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2020/12/09/biden-foreign-policy-iran/

So, a clash within the next two months (a pretty short time period) between Iran and the U.S. as defined by the question would be unwise for both, but especially for Iran, which has a lot to gain or loose from a less antagonistic American policy shift under a Joseph Biden administration. This not least relating to a return to the JCPOA or something similar. Iran will of course talk tough, but even statements from The Supreme Leader point further towards a pause to see what Biden will do (see AP link in question details). Is an assessment of the (un)wisdom of something the same as an assessment of its probability? No, but they are related. Some sort of confrontation is definately possible due to the ongoing proximity between Iranian and U.S. forces in The Persian Gulf (which I believe is far likelier than a confrontation inside Iran, which would be a more profound and rare). While a premeditated fight doesn't make any sense, an unintended escalation could always lead to violence. As noted below by @keith-huggins, Iran is recently (looking at past events) more likely to act through a proxy if it does act, for several purposes including (maybe) plausible deniability. Whatever the reason might be that would not apply to the question as defined by the details above. Biden will have a whole lot on his plate in the next few months not least domestically so any major shifts (to which Iran might react unhappily) seems unlikely to unfold within the given time frame. Will the Trump administration escalate tensions with Iran within the next two weeks? It's not exactly friendly to Iran but it doesn't seem to carry any advantages (apart from possibly smashing one's house on the way out) and Trump's recent "dialing down" statement after the Capitol unrest has reasonably been interpreted as him bowing under pressure to keep a lower profile until the inaguration. I would otherwise be tempted to set the probability of a "Yes" outcome as even lower, following the "That would be stupid" train of thought, but sometimes stupid things happen, and clashes in a relatively speaking crowded sea space is never a zero risk prospect. This all subject to revision if stuff changes, of course.

Always non-zero, especially when the two militaries (navies) are in daily contact. Nevertheless, but as this is specifically in Iran (not Syria or Iraq) or at sea and if we assume Obama's focus on a deal with Iran presages a similar policy under Biden and that Iran (both the government and IRGC) will already in some form of communication with Biden's team, it would take a rapid escalation for a calculated (as opposed to accidental) confrontation leading to a fatality.
Biden's Democrats are running the show. There will be war. Time will tell if this one is it.
It can happen at any time, as Dems control house and senate, they could be more relaxed if Iran fail to respect agreements.

Recent event in US will embolden other countries, the new president has a lot on plate domestically so it might be easy for something to slip abroad.  Balanced with having a president that is likely to manage to appoint staff now he has control of house and senate and is likely to be cautious.  Risk is relatively high at the mo, but not really high.
Iran knowns where the line is and won't cross it intenllay

There is always a nonzero chance of a lethal confrontation between the military forces of Iran and the U.S. in the waters off the coast of Iran, because the U.S. military ships are likely to at some points be in Iran's vicinity over the next two months and the actions of individual ship commanders are unpredictable. However, intentional conflict between the two countries is extremely unlikely because the Trump administration is distracted with domestic issues and the Iranian government will want to start its relationship with the incoming Biden administration off on the right foot.

Trump decision to hand over smoothly to Biden reduces chances of a last-minute rash move by US. Iran not likely to wish to provoke new administration if it wants to move back to the treaty / regain some form of trade and recognition. Outside chance of something involving Israel or Saudi Arabia dragging in US as well.
Unlikely unless it happens in the next 13 days.

Despite the fact that a medium or large scale conflict is highly unlikely before March 2021the prospect of tit for tat exchanges could take place should the US continue to target Iran for targeted specific attacks on key military figures as they have done in the past. Should Iran continue with terrorist attacks against US military personnel in Iraq then there is distinct possibility of at least one fatality. The incoming Biden administration should offer a more appeasing approach to US Iran relations and diplomacy over using the threat of the US military might should prevent escalation of military confrontation. Good trade relations should help and the need for Iran's need for help from the US for  their domestic COVID pandemic problem will also calm relations.

This has never happened and despite the tensions, the stakes are too high for both countries to have a military confrontation.

History shows that Iran uses proxies to engage in conflict that allows it to punch above their weight in the middle east. To engage in a confrontation with the US is probably unlikely.

Given that Biden’s administration is similar to that of Obama the new president may want to re-engage with the JCPOA, with Iran hoping for a reduction in sanctions by reducing nuclear activities.
Iran does not need to embarrass Trump given the current situation in Washington giving Biden time to calm things down.

15 march is very close, USA have other stuffs to deal with currently so they would do almost anything to avoid that kind of problem. Reducing geographically to Iran or at sea make it even less likely.  Only possibility is Trump losing it and nuking Iran or declaring war. The probability is extremely low, not 0 but very close.
Barring Donald Trump trying to create a diversion or an accidental encounter, neither has anything to gain; at least in this time frame.

In this short time frame any confrontation would likely be done by proxies or a drone shot down. More ramping up seems likely before either side would be willing to have a clash of official forces. Iran is desperately trying (its own strange way, South Korean tanker included) to get the US back to the JCPOA. A conflict would not help this purpose. Excluding the unpredictable Trump effect, chances are close to nil.

On last year’s similar question I came up with an estimate of 2 or 3 incidents that would trigger this question (plus about the same in near misses) over a 40 year period. That is 5% or 10% if you count near misses as half. This is two and a half months though so pro rata ing the annual rate gets you to 1 - 2%. However it feels like this is very unlikely in this time period. Trump could do something in the next week or so, but he has other things to focus on. I think early on both Iran and Biden will want to be cautious and feel each other out before escalating. Maybe it should be 25 - 50% of the normal run rate, which would get you to 0.25 - 1%. If we could go decimal I would probably go for 0.33%. Can’t so rounding to zero. It does feel like we should have some decimal options for the very likely or very unlikely!

I really feel like the correct answer is 0%. The move to enrich uranium to 20% and the seizure of a South Korean vessel should be interpreted as moves by the Iranian's to compel a Biden administration to come to the table - this time with a diminished position of strength. I think its a safe assumption that these acts of escalation will be dialed back in exchange for concessions, and that in fact these escalations were fabricated in order to have something to exchange. If there is a lethal confrontation it will almost certainly be by accident.
